General course objectives:
General course objectives
Based on solid definitions of security and its relationship to complexity theory, students will be introduced to the modern framework of cryptography.
Learning objectives:
A student who has met the objectives of the course will be able to:
Describe the notions of unconditional and asymptotic security
Explain concepts such as one-way or pseudorandom functions and outline their differences
Show how primitives such as one-way or pseudorandom functions can be used to build symmetric encryption schemes or hash functions
Show how complex primitives such as authenticated encryption arise from combinations of simpler concepts
Describe the sponge construction and the SHA-3 hash function
Visualize the use of differential cryptanalysis in examples, such as the application to the AES block cipher
Explain advanced cryptographic primitives such as commitment schemes and secret sharing
Explore the applicability of advanced cryptographic primitives in complex use-cases
Content: (Unconditional) Security, Complexity theory and cryptography, integrity and authentication, theory and practice of hash functions, analysis of block ciphers, commitment schemes and secret sharing
Remarks: The course is a sequel to the course 01410.
